Completed: 8/22/14 in 18 hrs.

This game will only seem appealing to a narrow group of players. If you were born in the 70s or to the 80s or wish to see where the FPS genre came from, then sure. Being as I am a retro gamer; I simply love this game. Not as nostalgic as the first but gold none the less.

In the early days of Quake and Doom the games were generally a one trick pony. In the Hexen and Heretic they implemented a inventory system as well as selectable character classes; something new to the genre and with this one a level up system even.

It's worst flaws are the dated graphics and some of the puzzles are quite frustrating. You must pay attention to detail and remember large levels to progress in any sort of enjoyable time/manner.

Steam should have the expansion... boo.

reviewText: On the plus side, the weapons are far less overpowered this time around, and the modified Quake engine allows for far more complex level design, on top of a 3D look that hasn't aged perfectly, but still is more pleasing to the eye than enemies that look like they're made from cardboard. They also played it up as much more of an RPG this time around, giving each class a set of visible stats that automatically level up when you've gained enough experience points from killing enemies, giving you an incentive to fight rather than just run past everything. The puzzles are also largely improved, most having solutions that don't require you to activate some unknown wall or something. No, this game will tell you, and you'll probably be able to figure it out without a guide.\nOn the negative side, the Quake engine. While it's good to look at and everything, you'll have to do a bit of tweaking to get the resolution accurate, set mouse controls, and all that stuff, and it all has to be done manually. It's not a huge complaint, but it's just a quick pain that you have to go through whenever you install the game.\nEven if you weren't a fan of the previous games, I'd suggest giving this one a go.

reviewText: Based off of the original quake engine, Hexen II is quite stunning in both it's technical aspects and its overall appeal as a game. Continuing where the original Hexen left-off, this game adds some twist in the medival storyline, expands the Hexen universe, and provides us gamers with an easily digestable narrative. Gameplay-wise Hexen II puts an emphasis on ranged combat, but melee combat also feels very satisfying (seeming as you can decapitate and quarter your foes once they're down). The leveling system isn't robust, but because the game is more action-oriented the RPG elements are more of an addition rather than a main attraction. The wide variety of enemies and open world compliments the different classes to play as, and substantially increases the replayablility. Overall if you're on the fence about getting this classical masterpiece or if you seem vaguely interested in the vintage fps genre, GET IT!! You won't regret this purchase.

reviewText:
Feeling sad by writing this review but... After playing some old school shooters like Doom, Quake, Heretic and Hexen 1 itself, I cant recommend this game.

Presentation

The game itself looks and plays great. It runs in an altered Quake 1 engine and is fully 3d, unlike Hexen 1, which, just like Doom, uses 2d sprites for enemies and items. I have no ploblems running this game on my machine (win. 8). The environments and enemies bring a gothic and dark feeling, with great soundtrack that emphasises the overall grim atmosphere that the game has. Just like Hexen 1 you chose a few character classes that have different weapons and use the two types of mana in different ways. Its kind of an attempt to include RPG elements in a shooter.

Puzzles and Problems

Eventhough it looks and plays great, the reason why I dont recommend this game is that its virtually impossible to advance the game without some kind of guide or walkthrough. The shooting and killing is sporadic, and you will spend most of the time trying to solve hundreds of impossible puzzles, that require you to go to a certain location, pick up a hidden item, then teleport to another location, pull that lever... Its not a shooter like Quake, the devs pick up the simple puzzles from Hexen 1 and created something really annoying, that requires you to be constantly looking for answers on the internet as you just cant figure out by yourself using exploration. If you want a good fast paced shooter like Duke Nukem, Quake and Heretic, this game is not for you.

Get Hexen 1, Heretic or Quake instead.

reviewText:
I've been a fan of Hexen and Hexen II since my youth. I decided I'd give this game another shot and ultimately, I still think it's a pretty good game in general. It's fun to explore and the fact each classes have different weapons gives the game some replay value. Most of the puzzles in the game are reasonable although they get a little harder later in the game. The game has some pretty good music but as far as I know, it doesn't have files for CD music so it means you might be stuck with Midi. The first attempt to clear the game might take a pretty good amount of time as well so for a first person adventure game, it's length is pretty reasonable.

However, this is a game I'd only recommend to people who aren't impatient. There's a fair share of exploration required to do and at times and some of the puzzles can be rather frustrating or some hints can be somewhat unclear. At some point, areas might open to continue progression but it's not always perfectly clear where you're supposed to go next. The last few worlds are particularly bad in that regard but I wouldn't say it ever gets unfair. On the other hand, I'd say Hexen did a better job in general to figure out what has to be done or at least, the exploration doesn't get as tedious.

Still, anyone who's willing to explore the game and have the patience to understand the puzzles will most likely have a fun experience. Some of the areas are actually memorable with how they've been designed and I'd say the maps gets even more fun to visit as the game progresses.

reviewText:
Poor game from a poor series.  Not worth your time or money.

Get Quake instead.  It's a different genere of game but it's still manages to be better in every way.

The combat in Hexen II is clunky and made difficult by the inability to freely use the mouse without holding a button.
Bugs prevented me from progressing (such as doors refusing to open as scripted).  Poor level design also caused unsolvable issues - such as jumping into a shallow pool that had a ledge higher than you could jump, permanently trapping you.

At points I had to bring up the console and use 'noclip' just to get past moments that bugged.  This wasn't due to me missing  part of the puzzle either, as I referenced everything online.

Literally everything, the puzzles are so obscure and without any logical context that I had to use a walkthrough for most of my playthrough.

Pace is further interrupted with difficult to see switches and hidden areas that are obtusely hidden, requiring attrition and general time wasting tactics to find.

There is just no flow to anything, the combat is difficult due to poor controls, the puzzles non-sensical and the level design made to waste your time.

This game isn't worth anyone's time or money.  It may be very cheap, but why would you pay anything to be frustrated?

I've written a more detailed review of this game and the series in General here:

http://theboilingpot.net/hexen-ii/

One of several games that utterly fascinated me as a child, it only barely makes it's way into my list of games I like and am willing to keep around, only because I think the paladin is awesome.
